Graphical abstract The Cu (2 0 0) surface has a lower C–C coupling energy barrier through specific *CO adsorption configuration (*COhollow), which significantly promotes the formation of C2 products. Electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) provides a sustainable and green strategy for converting CO2 into valuable chemicals, especially for C2 products. However, the poor C2-product selectivity of catalysts related to substantial activation energy required for C–C coupling severely limits the practical application of ECR. Herein, we systematically investigate the role of crystal facet engineering on modulating the performance of copper-based catalysts, which achieves selective ECR for C2 products through the regulation of key intermediate adsorption configurations. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations, combined with various characterization methods, indicate that the exposure of specific crystal facets on the copper surface plays a critical role in determining the selectivity of the products. Compared to the *CO top adsorption on Cu (1 1 1), the specific *CO adsorption in the hollow site on the Cu (2 0 0) facet significantly lowers the energy barrier for C–C coupling. As a result, the SCF3 sputtered copper film sample with Cu (1 1 1) and Cu (2 0 0) facets shows a high C2 product selectivity with a Faradaic efficiency of 70.6 ± 2.0 %, while the SCF1 sample with single Cu (1 1 1) facet shows a Faradaic efficiency of CH4 at 49.8 ± 2.4 %. This work highlights the key role of facet-modulated *CO adsorption configuration in boosting the ECR performance and the selectivity of C2 products for Cu-based materials. Keywords Facet-dependent *CO adsorption configuration Electrochemical CO2 reduction Sputtered copper catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) into valuable chemicals and fuels represented by C2 products offers a promising solution for CO2 resource utilization [1–4]. The development of efficient catalysts is key to advancing the practical application of ECR. Among various candidates, copper-based catalysts have emerged as the promising candidate materials for ECR, especially for the synthesis of C2 product, yet the C2 selectivity of copper-based catalysts is still poor [5–7]. A considerable body of research has focused on modifying copper-based catalysts to alter product selectivity, employing a range of strategies such as the construction of heterojunctions [8–11], doping with both metal and non-metal elements [12–15], regulation of interface environment [16–19], and the regulation of exposed crystal facets [20–22]. Crystal facet engineering, which focuses on selectively exposing specific crystal facets, is considered an effective approaches to improve the C2 selectivity and catalytic performance of Cu-based materials among various strategies [23]. For instance, Jiang et al. successfully synthesized a copper electrocatalyst enriched with Cu (1 0 0) facets using a metal ion battery cycling approach. Both experimental and theoretical analyses revealed that Cu (1 0 0) and stepped (2 1 1) facets show superior performance in promoting the C–C coupling reaction, leading to significantly enhanced ethylene selectivity [24]. Wang et al. achieved a notable enhancement in C2 product selectivity by optimizing the exposure of the Cu (1 0 0) facet through electrochemical deposition of copper catalysts. This improvement was attributed to the effective control of key intermediates involved in the ECR process [25]. Despite these advances, the intrinsic effects of different crystal facets on intermediate conversion and C2 selectivity remain poorly understood, posing a significant challenge for further optimization To investigate the mechanism related to the Cu crystal-facet control on ECR, the study on the adsorption behavior of critical intermediates, particularly *CO, is essential in determining the reaction pathway and product selectivity. The configuration of *CO adsorption on the catalyst surface is critical in influencing the efficiency of C–C coupling [26,27]. Researches have reported the effects of top adsorption (*COtop), bridge adsorption (*CObridge), hollow adsorption (*COhollow) configurations on C–C coupling activity [28,29]. For example, Li et al. realized to control the adsorption configuration of *CO by adjusting the mesostructure of CuO and demonstrated that the *COtop site is more likely to facilitate the formation of C2H4, ultimately tuning the product distribution of C2+ species [27]. However, research on *COhollow adsorption remains limited due to challenges such as the complex coordination environment and the risk of CO poisoning caused by excessive adsorption strength. These limitations have hindered a deeper understanding of *COhollow and its potential impact on ECR efficiency and selectivity. However, *COhollow sites can enable C–C coupling by shortening adjacent carbon distances (near C–C bond length) for efficient orbital overlap, while charge transfer to the substrate creates electrophilic carbon that readily bonds covalently with another carbon species. To address the challenge presented above, the choice of a suitable model catalyst is crucial for elucidating the catalytic mechanism of C2 product formation. Single-component Cu catalysts have garnered considerable interest due to their well-defined active sites and simplicity in mechanistic studies. Notably, these Cu catalysts are commonly fabricated through electrochemical deposition method, where the growth of copper can be precisely controlled by modifying the deposition parameters and the environment. However, there still remains some drawbacks related on the synthesis of single Cu catalysts, including uneven deposition and the difficulty in controlling the surface area. Therefore, developing a new approach to prepare facet-dependent single Cu catalysts is highly desirable. Here, we developed a single copper catalyst by a precise magnetron sputtering strategy for efficient ECR to C2 products. It offers a highly scalable and cost-effective alternative that enables rapid, uniform deposition over large areas without complex electrolyte systems. The technique’s compatibility with industrial roll-to-roll processes and minimal raw material waste further enhances its economic viability. Through systematically exploring the sputtering conditions, Cu films with varying crystal facet exposures can be obtained, which significantly influence the selectivity between methane and ethylene. Experimental results show that at lower sputtering power, the Cu film predominantly exposes the (1 1 1) facet, while higher sputtering power results in the exposure of both the (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) facets. When the Cu catalyst primarily exposes the Cu (1 1 1) facet, methane is the predominant product. In contrast, when both the Cu (1 1 1) and Cu (2 0 0) facets are exposed, ethylene becomes the major product, suggesting that an increased exposure of the Cu (2 0 0) facet promotes a higher yield of C2 products. This finding confirms that the Cu (2 0 0) facet is essential for enhancing the ECR process, particularly in the formation of C2 products, with the maximum FE of approximately 70.6 ± 2.0 % from the champion catalyst. Theoretical calculations further demonstrated that the specific *CO adsorption configuration (*COhollow) on the Cu (2 0 0) surface facilitates C–C coupling. Additionally, the higher free energy for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the Cu (2 0 0) facet effectively suppresses side reactions. These findings underscore the critical importance of facet exposure control in optimizing Cu-based catalysts for ECR. By selectively exposing specific facets, it is possible to direct the reaction pathways and enhance the overall efficiency and selectivity of the ECR process. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Materials Potassium hydroxide (KOH, purity > 85 %) was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Carbon paper (YLS-30T), and anion exchange membrane (FAA-3-PK-130) were obtained from Suzhou Sinero Technology Co. Ltd. High purity CO2 (99.99 %), high purity Ar (99.9 %) were provided by Xi'an Tenglong Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Material synthesis This study employed magnetron sputtering to synthesize copper films deposited on carbon paper. The magnetron sputtering system is manufactured by Beijing Chuangshiweina Technology Co., LTD., with the model number: MSP-300B. According to the instrument parameters, the deposition rate reaches 65 nm/min at a sputtering power of 100 W. During the deposition process, the Ar flow rate is maintained at 50 sccm. During sputtering, the chamber pressure is maintained at 8 × 10−4 Pa. Additionally, the sputtering power and duration were precisely adjusted to obtain copper films with distinct microstructural and morphological characteristics. By changing the sputtering power and time, a series of copper film catalysts were prepared, namely SCF1, SCF2, SCF3 (the power gradually increased, corresponding to 50 W, 100 W, 300 W respectively, and the time was 30S), 2-SCF1, 2-SCF2, 2-SCF3 (the power gradually increased, corresponding to 50 W, 100 W, 300 W respectively, and the time was 60S). For an expression similar to 20 W-30S, the sputtering power is 20 W, and the sputtering time is 30S. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The morphological information of the samples was obtained using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (MAIA3 LMH, TESCAN). The XRD measurements were performed using a Rigaku Smart-Lab diffractometer in standard θ-2θ continuous scan mode. The chemical states of copper species on the sample surface were analyzed using a K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with an Al-Kα radiation source, through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The water contact angle was measured using a DSA100 (KRUSS) system to evaluate the hydrophilicity of the catalyst surface. The surface morphology of the sample was characterized using an Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) (SPM-9700HT, SHIMADZU). The microstructure of the sample surface was observed by double spherical aberration corrected field emission transmission electron microscopy (Themis Z, FEI). 2.4 In situ ATR-FTIR measurements A small amount of sample solution was dropped onto a silicon wafer coated with a gold film and dried in preparation for further testing. The testing solution used was a 1 M potassium bicarbonate (KHCO3) solution. Initially, CO2 was bubbled through the solution for 30 min to establish the necessary conditions. The open circuit potential (OCP) signal was recorded first, followed by signal collection at each applied potential after a 15–20 s stabilization period. 2.5 Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction measurements Electrochemical studies were conducted using a workstation (KOSTER) in a flow cell setup. The flow cell consists of three main compartments: a gas chamber, a cathode chamber, and an anode chamber. The working electrode is placed between the gas chamber and the cathode chamber, while the counter electrode is located in the anode chamber. The Hg/HgO reference electrode is used for potential measurements. A 1 M KOH aqueous solution is continuously circulated in both the cathode and anode chambers at a rate of 8 mL min−1. CO2 gas was introduced into the gas chamber at a controlled flow rate of 40 mL min−1 via a mass flow controller. Gas phase products are analyzed by gas chromatograph. The liquid phase product is quantified by Agilent liquid chromatography. The Faradaic Efficiency (FE) of gaseous products were calculated as below: (1) FE gas = F ∗ N ∗ P ∗ υ ∗ x R ∗ T ∗ I × 100 % F: Faraday constant 96,485C mol−1; I: the current during the reaction; P: the pressure during the test; R: the molar gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1); ʋ: the CO2 flow rate; x: the concentration of the target product; N: the number of transferred electrons generated from a gaseous molecule; T: the temperature in terms of thermodynamics during testing. The FE of liquid phase products was calculated as below: (2) FE liquid = V ∗ C ∗ N ∗ F Q × 100 % V: volume of cathode electrolyte added; C: molar volume concentration of liquid product; F: 96,485 C mol−1; N: the number of transferred electrons generated from a liquid molecule; Q: total number of transferred electrons. 2.6 DFT calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP), incorporating projected augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials for precise electronic structure modeling [30–33]. The exchange–correlation effects were incorporated using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The cutoff energy was set to 500 eV. The convergence criteria for force and energy were set to 0.02 eV/Å and 10−5 eV, respectively. The Cu (2 0 0) and Cu (1 1 1) crystal planes were cut and exposed, respectively. To mitigate periodic interactions, a vacuum thickness of 20 Å was introduced above the surfaces during the calculations. A (3 × 3 × 1) K-point mesh was used for the calculations. The transition state calculations were performed using the VASP software in combination with the Climbing Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method. Initial and final states were fully optimized with convergence criteria of 10−6 eV for energy and −0.02 eV/Å for force, ensuring atomic index consistency and path continuity. Four intermediate images (IMAGES = 4) were used to construct the initial path. The climbing image algorithm was enabled during iterations to locate the energy maximum until force convergence was achieved. By comparing the theoretical results with experimental data, key factors that govern the selectivity of the copper films in ECR reactions can be identified. Under high applied potentials, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) competes with the ECR at the cathode, leading to a decline in product selectivity. Such enhanced electronic interaction is favorable for facilitating the subsequent and coupling and hydrogenation process. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study underscores the potential of magnetron sputtering to precisely control the exposed crystal facets of copper-based catalysts, thereby optimizing the ECR for enhanced C2 product formation. By adjusting sputtering power, distinct crystal facets of copper are selectively exposed, leading to a modulation in product selectivity. Specifically, for SCF1, the Cu (1 1 1) facet predominates, resulting in CH4 as the major product with a FE of 49.8 ± 2.4 %. For SCF2 and SCF3, the exposure of Cu (2 0 0) facets significantly promotes C–C coupling processes, which elevates the C2 products with the FE rising to 70.6 ± 2.0 %. DFT calculations further confirmed that the Cu (2 0 0) surface lowers the energy barrier of C–C coupling due to its unique *COhollow configuration, leading to more efficient C–C bond formation. Moreover, it further elucidates that the Cu (1 1 1) facet has a lower free energy for the HER compared to the Cu (2 0 0) facet, making it more prone to the HER side reactions. These results underscore the importance of facet control in optimizing Cu-based electrocatalysts for ECR. This research presents a practical approach to improving the efficiency and selectivity of ECR for the relationship of the crystal facets through the precise regulation of sputtering power. Moreover, the magnetron-sputtered large-area copper films demonstrate promising and important industrial applicability, as their facet-controlled uniformity enables direct electrolyzer integration while the binder-free design enhances mechanical stability and reduces manufacturing costs. The sputtering technique itself offers inherent advantages for scalable production. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical CO2 reduction (ECR) provides a sustainable and green strategy for converting CO2 into valuable chemicals, especially for C2 products. However, the poor C2-product selectivity of catalysts related to substantial activation energy required for C–C coupling severely limits the practical application of ECR. Herein, we systematically investigate the role of crystal facet engineering on modulating the performance of copper-based catalysts, which achieves selective ECR for C2 products through the regulation of key intermediate adsorption configurations. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations, combined with various characterization methods, indicate that the exposure of specific crystal facets on the copper surface plays a critical role in determining the selectivity of the products. Compared to the *CO top adsorption on Cu (1 1 1), the specific *CO adsorption in the hollow site on the Cu (2 0 0) facet significantly lowers the energy barrier for C–C coupling. As a result, the SCF3 sputtered copper film sample with Cu (1 1 1) and Cu (2 0 0) facets shows a high C2 product selectivity with a Faradaic efficiency of 70.6 ± 2.0 %, while the SCF1 sample with single Cu (1 1 1) facet shows a Faradaic efficiency of CH4 at 49.8 ± 2.4 %. This work highlights the key role of facet-modulated *CO adsorption configuration in boosting the ECR performance and the selectivity of C2 products for Cu-based materials.
